misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they check for an integer using sc.hasNextInt() and it returns false, the Scanner will automatically skip over the 'invalid' token and move to the next one for the subsequent loop iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not realize that the Scanner's read pointer only advances when a consumption method (like next() or nextInt()) is called. hasNextInt() is a non-consuming 'peek'. If it returns false because the next token is not an integer, that token remains at the front of the input buffer. In this code, if one invalid token is encountered, all subsequent attempts to read a score will fail on that same token, filling the rest of the array with 0.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if a conditional check like 'hasNextInt()' fails, the program can simply assign a default value (like 0) and move to the next iteration of the loop to process the next piece of data, without realizing that the invalid token remains at the front of the Scanner's buffer.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand the mechanics of the Scanner's read pointer. When 'hasNextInt()' returns false because the next token is not an integer, that token is not consumed. In a loop, subsequent calls to 'hasNextInt()' will repeatedly peek at the same invalid token, resulting in the remainder of the array being filled with the default value while the Scanner 'stuck' behind the invalid input.
